Please be careful about this update. Xerces 2.11.0 started to implement `ElementTraversal` on its `ElementImpl`s, but that class is not present in JDK 8's rt.jar - it is shipped from JDK9 onwards (java.xml module).

I've encountered this situation in other project; if the JDK8 runtime attempts Xerces' DOM implementation (`ElementImpl`), it will fail with `ClassDefNotFoundError` -- 

> public class org.apache.xerces.dom.ElementImpl extends org.apache.xerces.dom.ParentNode implements org.w3c.dom.Element,org.w3c.dom.**ElementTraversal**,org.w3c.dom.TypeInfo 

JDK9+ is fine.

If you want Xerces 2.11+ to be fully functional od JDK8, you need to add e.g. xml-apis.jar that contains the class.

netbeans$ for i in platform/net.java.html*; do ant -f $i maven-install || break; done

Hello Martin, thanks for the cleanup.

If you removed all compilation warnings from the module, should you also make sure that once a new warning is introduced, the compilation fails?

Because without such automatic check your work may not last. Traditionally the NetBeans community never paid much attention to warnings - as such I wouldn't even noticed if I re-introduced a warning.

There is a `-Werror` javac flag. You should enable it when setting the `javac.compilerargs` property. Or (better) change `common.xml` to support a new property `javac.failOnWarnings=false` (`false` by default) that each cleaned up module could set to `true`.
Work in #1746 is also touching the same `scripting.sh` file.

> keep the branch yet for a while

If this PR is dormant, then let's close the PR! I don't want to prevent anyone to fix the tests or update the parser to more recent specs, but it seems that people are in general OK with the parser as currently integrated and I see no strive to drive this PR to conclusion.

Btw. I am closing just the PR, the branch stays untouched.

Done

> Hello Martin, thanks for the cleanup.
> 
> If you removed all compilation warnings from the module, should you also make sure that once a new warning is introduced, the compilation fails?
> 
> Because without such automatic check your work may not last. Traditionally the NetBeans community never paid much attention to warnings - as such I wouldn't even noticed if I re-introduced a warning.

I fully agree with you.

However, the only thing I've accomplished is correcting the linter warnings for specific types - namely the one listed in the description of this PR. With the current value of the `javac.compilerargs` property no more linter warnings are produced. This however does not mean that the compiler does not produce no warnings. The following warnings are an exerpt of the warning still produced during the build process:

```
.../nbbuild/build/public-package-jars/org-netbeans-api-annotations-common.jar(/org/netbeans/api/annotations/common/NonNull.class): warning: Cannot find annotation method 'when()' in type 'Nonnull': class file for javax.annotation.Nonnull not found
warning: unknown enum constant When.ALWAYS
  reason: class file for javax.annotation.meta.When not found
.../nbbuild/build/public-package-jars/org-netbeans-api-annotations-common.jar(/org/netbeans/api/annotations/common/NullAllowed.class): warning: Cannot find annotation method 'when()' in type 'Nonnull'
warning: unknown enum constant When.MAYBE
warning: No processor claimed any of these annotations: org.netbeans.api.annotations.common.NullAllowed,org.netbeans.api.annotations.common.NonNull
```

Setting the `-Werror` javac flag then causes the build to fail rather fast.

```
error: warnings found and -Werror specified
1 error
5 warnings
```

I have not investigated what causes these messages nor how to fix them. That would propably be a job for someone that is more knowledgeable with the NetBeans buildsystem.

> There is a `-Werror` javac flag. You should enable it when setting the `javac.compilerargs` property. Or (better) change `common.xml` to support a new property `javac.failOnWarnings=false` (`false` by default) that each cleaned up module could set to `true`.

My - at this stage rather pragmatic - opinion would be to add the `-Werror` to the `javac.compilerargs` property. Anyone acustomed to javac and its commandline argument knows what that does.
Admittably a new property `javac.failOnWarnings=false` has its charm as well but who knows how it is used in the build.

Just a gut feelling...

> Great, thanks for the clean ups.

Thanks. Can I coount you as a reviewer?
This one looks good to me, approved.

BTW is there a reason that the FlatLaf jar is renamed from `flatlaf-0.21.jar` to `com-formdev-flatlaf.jar` in `nbbuild/netbeans/platform/modules/ext`, while all other jars in `ext` keep their original names?

I would prefer to keep the original name (including version number).

@jGauravGupta you can merge this yourself. However be careful with the "Squash and merge" option in the github GUI. If the account of the author is not configured correctly, it will create invalid author information. In this case @MeroRai does not have a public email address configured for this account, so this will create a squash commit without a valid email.

In this case please squash outside github (IMHO the github UI is useless as is) and push the squashed commit directly. When you squash manually the author information will be retained, you will be marked as committer.

Well the name change is not necessary. It happened  due to one my early attempt so get the jar included into the module system. It is usually a good practice to remove the version from the jar, so when you update the module it gets overwritten and does not accumulate up in the user dir. However with built-in modules it is not that important either (updates are usually delivered with new releases).
So do what you wish for renaming.

Ok, thanks, I'll rename it.

Another question: is there any documentation on howto update external libraries?
I managed it somehow, but maybe there is a better way.

What I did:
1. open `binaries-list` in editor and change version
2. build project, which tells me the hash is wrong and shows the correct hash
3. copy correct hash to `binaries-list`
4. rename license file
5. open `nbproject/project.properties`, `nbproject/project.xml` and license file in editor and change versions
6. build

Is this the right way? Thanks.

4.5 Change the versions in the license file (you did that as well)

But pretty much that covers the procedure. When there is some change in the exposed API-s it is wise to increase the module version number in the manifest.mf as well.

File access was already present in the original code and also in the current releases of netbeans. The only change I have made is replace file paths with URL schemes.

I do think the overall history handling could benefit from code overhaul. But what alternative remains to support remote files? This may become more important, now that talks of a cloud based netbeans are ongoing.
Please suggest me if you have any workarounds.

The problem with [JSR-305](https://jcp.org/en/jsr/detail?id=305) is that it is dormant. It will never become a Java standard and its use of `javax.` packages may thus be unjustified.

When solving this with Petr Hejl we decided not to expose the JSR-305 annotation during runtime and use those annotations only internally, during compile time.

My Ubuntu returns `dellxps/127.0.1.1` (the value I have in my `etc/hosts`) as the `myIpAddressEx()`. The builder machine returns `localhost/127.0.0.1`. The `PacEngineTest` then breaks. I believe the test is buggy, but I haven't yet understood the code to be sure.

Ok - for me local file access and network access fall into to different categories:

For local file access you can normally expect quick responses and thus get away with running it on the EDT. To be clear: It should not be done on the EDT (virus scanners, mounted network drives), but it can work.

For the remote part all bets are off. If you are on a high latency link round trip times in the range of seconds are possible and this is a no-go on the EDT.

The suggestion I have: Move things that may be caught doing high latency work into a background thread (RequestProcessor).

The  `/etc/hosts` file in my vm was like this:
```
127.0.0.1	localhost
127.0.1.1	netbeans

# The following lines are desirable for IPv6 capable hosts
::1     ip6-localhost ip6-loopback
fe00::0 ip6-localnet
ff00::0 ip6-mcastprefix
ff02::1 ip6-allnodes
ff02::2 ip6-allrouters
```
The localhost is the first entry in the file and I changed the order of the hosts entries in the file setting the localhost entry after the hostmane entry.
```
127.0.1.1	netbeans
127.0.0.1	localhost

# The following lines are desirable for IPv6 capable hosts
::1     ip6-localhost ip6-loopback
fe00::0 ip6-localnet
ff00::0 ip6-mcastprefix
ff02::1 ip6-allnodes
ff02::2 ip6-allrouters
```

Seems that Travis environment define the localhost entry is the last entry in the `/etc/host` file when it is generated.
```

127.0.0.1 localhost nettuno travis vagrant travis-job-f156679e-fe7a-4976-b2b2-bd2c39f087d1 
```

@lkishalmi Have you tried the "Small Toolbar Icons" option? (Available by right-clicking the main NetBeans toolbar.) What do you think about enabling this option by default, in all LAFs?

Enabling "Small Toolbar Icons" by default will have one advantage in the future, when we slowly start replacing bitmap toolbar icons with SVG versions. Currently, the toolbar requires two icon versions of each action--both 16x16 and 24x24. This is a hassle--in the future I imagine there will be just a single SVG image for each action which can be scaled to either size. It would be best if this could be a 16x16 version, which is then automatically scaled up to 24x24 if "Small Toolbar Icons" is disabled. Since this will scale up border widths as well, though, this means toolbar icons will look slightly more consistent in "Small Toolbar Icons" mode.

Build fails on sigtest public API signature test. One possible solution is to increase the Major Release version.
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/1381701/70655027-589b9d00-1c0c-11ea-8ae0-2fbebe962359.png)

It needs to be added in the FlatLaf Look and Feel Project metadata as well:
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/1381701/70655175-a4e6dd00-1c0c-11ea-920c-8db99d62cf23.png)
Restarted failing Travis jobs to see if it passes now. One issue was the usual hibernate dependenct, I haven't checked the other.

_No_ hibernate is not (as was never) the issue of unittest failures. I wager you mean this message:

```
 Scanning for modules in /home/matthias/src/netbeans
[insert-module-all-targets] Cannot find build prerequisite org.netbeans.modules.hibernate of /home/matthias/src/netbeans/contrib/hibernateweb
```

This is always there (at least for two years) since hibernate was removed. It can be easily fixed by removing hibernateweb from contrib or reincluding hibernate into contrib. It is just normaly not in the focus because the netbeans build is chatty as hell. It would be great if everybody could stop jumping to this conclusion.

I'm not sure what to make with this. It is a fact, that the JSR305 classes (or at least the symbols) already leaked out of the module. Javac might have been more forgiving in the past, but it is not anymore.

I see two options:
- rip the Common Annotations dependency out of the modules and then remove the module altogether and get rid of the annotations
- update Common Annotations to not carry the JSR305 annotations

One questions remains: Do we gain anything or would it make more sense to keep the library and at least satisfy javac?

@lkishalmi thanks for the info and for the solution.

While I understand what sigtest is good for, I actually don't understand that it fails in this case.
I've just exported more packages, which adds API, but does not change or remove API.

> One possible solution is to increase the Major Release version.

Just curious, what other solutions are possible?

Hidden return type (can't convert) : com.formdev.flatlaf.ui.FlatSpinnerUI$Handler in method public com.formdev.flatlaf.ui.FlatSpinnerUI$Handler com.formdev.flatlaf.ui.FlatSpinnerUI.getHandler()
